data.title: Translation as Taking Stances: The Emergence of Syriac Theodoranism in 5th Century Edessa
data.abstractNote: The sheer dimensions of the theological and ecclesio-political consequences of Theodor of Mopsuestia’s reception by eastern Syriac schools, theologians and bishops, a reception that shaped eastern Syriac Christianity like no other intellectual factor, raises the question of what triggered the reception process in the first place - about the concrete intentions behind the initiation of the Syriac Theodore translation project in fourth century Edessa, which formed the basis for all Syriac Theodore reception. An investigation of the historical contexts of this translation project suggests that the project first started as a reaction to the simultaneous promotion of Syriac Cyrillianism by bishop Rabbula of Edessa. It also points out the close connection between the translation project’s emergence on the one hand and the (theological only, at first) Syriac Cyrillians-Theodorans divide as well as the later schism between Miaphysites and Nestorians on the other.
